factoid: Weyrother gave that smile again.
The smile seemed to say that it was strange and ridiculous for Weyrother to meet objections from Russian generals.
Weyrother had to prove to Russian generals what he had convinced himself of.
Weyrother had convinced sovereign Emperors of the same matter.
Weyrother said that the enemy had quenched its fires.
Weyrother said that a continual noise was heard from the enemy's camp.
Weyrother said that the enemy might be retreating.
Weyrother said that the enemy might be changing its position.
If the enemy was retreating, that was the only thing they needed to fear.
If the enemy was changing its position, that was a different situation.
Weyrother smiled ironi­cally.
Weyrother said that even if the enemy also took up a position in the Thuerassa, it would save them a great deal of trouble.
Weyrother said that all their arrangements to the minutest detail would remain the same.
Prince Andrew began asking, 'How is that?'
Prince Andrew had been waiting for an opportunity to express his doubts.
Kutúzov woke up.
Kutúzov coughed heavily.
Kutúzov looked around at the generals.
Kutúzov said that the dispositions for tomorrow could not be altered.
Kutúzov said that the dispositions for today could not be altered because it was past midnight.
Kutúzov said that they had heard the dispositions and would all do their duty.
Kutúzov said that before a battle, the most important thing is to have a good sleep.
Kutúzov moved as if to rise.
The generals bowed and retired.
It was past midnight.
Prince Andrew went out.
The council of war left Prince Andrew with a vague and uneasy impression.
Prince Andrew had not been able to express his opinion at the council of war.
Prince Andrew did not know whether Dolgorúkov and Weyrother, or Kutúzov, Langeron, and others who did not approve of the plan of attack were right.
Prince Andrew wondered if it was not possible for Kutúzov to state his views plainly to the Emperor.
Prince Andrew wondered if, due to court and personal considerations, tens of thousands of lives and his own life were at risk.
Prince Andrew thought that it was very likely he would be killed tomorrow.
The thought of death caused a series of distant and intimate memories to rise in Prince Andrew's imagination.
Prince Andrew remembered his last parting from his father.
Prince Andrew remembered his last parting from his wife.
Prince Andrew remembered the days when he first loved his wife.
Prince Andrew thought of his wife's pregnancy.
Prince Andrew felt sorry for his wife.
Prince Andrew felt sorry for himself.
Prince Andrew went out of the hut where he was billeted with Nesvítski.
Prince Andrew began to walk up and down before the hut.
